Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Interdisciplinary (99)
Exploring Science in the Studio is expanding a pedagogical approach that embeds science into courses in the fine arts, design, architecture, and creative writing. The project is engaged in developing and disseminating new pedagogical approaches and non-lab based instructional materials to deliver science content to humanities students. The outputs will be specially-designed and produced mobile units for scientific exploration. These mobile units will provide a replicable and scalable process for bringing science instructional materials directly into classrooms at colleges that do not have stand-alone science departments or facilities. This project has two goals: 1) To enable students in such colleges to understand the transferability of scientific methods of inquiry and knowledge to their practices in art, design, and writing; and 2) To help the humanities faculties in these colleges to integrate science into their teaching on the topic of sustainability. Sustainability is the science focus because of its substantial breadth, and because problems arising from climate change and the need for increased sustainability in the use of natural resources will be increasingly addressed by teams of individuals who contribute not only scientific knowledge, but creativity and innovation. Artists and designers have important roles to play on such teams.

POR.DRECONTENT:
“Exploring Science in the Studio” examined science education in the context of an art and design college, the California College of the Arts (CCA). The findings of the project are transferable to comparably sized colleges of art and design with a similar range of programs, majors and areas of focus as well as to other interdisciplinary areas of undergraduate science education at colleges and universities in general.

The project was successful in establishing vital infrastructure toward achieving two goals:

The project had two goals:

  1. To enable students in such colleges to understand the transferability of scientific methods of inquiry and knowledge to their practices in art, design, and writing; and

  2. To help the studio faculties in these colleges to integrate science into their teaching and to enrich the materials and equipment available to science and other faculty.

“Exploring Science in the Studio” featured three components:

  1. Science in the Studio (SitS) Courses featuring collaborations among art and design studio faculty and scientists

  2. MUSE System (Mobile Units for Scientific Exploration) for use within art and design studios

  3. Symposium to share findings among members of the Association of Independent Colleges of Art and Design (AICAD) and greater university community

1. Science in the Studio (SitS) Courses

The project facilitated the collaboration between art and design studio faculty and scientists from outside the college within 4-9 designated undergraduate studio classes during each fall semester of the grant period. The grant supported the participation of scientists in a total of eighteen classes through meaningful engagements and interactions with students and faculty. In some cases, the visiting scientists collaborated with the studio faculty in the development of course syllabi and activities. More often, the visiting scientists participated in the classes at several key points in the semester presenting scientific information relevant to the class and engaging with student questions and work. Alongside these classes, CCA also assessed its equipment and materials for science education and acquired additional new materials for use in science instruction by our own science faculty. A portion of these resources included materials designed for mobility, such that they may be moved from classroom to classroom in the absence of designated science laboratory space.

2. MUSE System - Mobile Units for Scientific Exploration

The aim of the MUSE is two-fold: to improve the quality of science instruction in science courses at CCA and to integrate science more fully into the studio curricula.  The MUSE system and the science materials, equipment, and collections created a new model for semi-permanent and movable science classroom and lab space that allows flexibility and innovation in bringing science both into and out of the classroom, the laboratory, the field, and the studio. The MUSE units expanded from a stand-alone cart to a system that incorporates carts, trays, kits, and soft storage (totes, backpacks) into a larger storage and display unit, housed in the CCA Libraries. The system evolved from our identification of several needs for the science materials (storage, access, and display) as well as several dichotomies in the nature of the intended materials: tiny/large, cheap/valuable, fragile/durable, light/heavy, mobile/stationary, field use/classroom use. The units are available to any CCA faculty member or student who attends training workshops on their use. The CCA library provides a permanent storage, display, and work site for the school’s science materials, centralizing these resources in a location utilized by students and faculty from all of CCA’s 21 undergraduate and 13 graduate majors. By increasing faculty and student access to scientific materials, equipment, and collections, the MUSE blurs the boundaries between the science classroom and the studio, inspired by the joy of discovery and wonder at the natural world.

3. AICAD Exploring Science in the [Art + Design] Studio Symposium

In November 2015, CCA organized and hosted a three-day conference with a keynote by Natalie Jeremijenko, an exhibition of student work from the Science in the Studio courses, a robust schedule of case studies, panels, and artist's talks, workshops and field trips, and a poster session. The Symposium assembled 300+ scholars, scientists, administrators, and tech industry leaders to share experiences and information about the integration of science into the art and design curriculum.  An exhibition featured student work that was created within the nine science courses offered at CCA during fall 2015. This exhibition was open to the campus and local communities.  Additionally, the symposium webpage (http://exploringscienceinthestudio.cca.edu) remains active and serves as a repository for additional dissemination of the results of the grant to the public.
